trial_identification.studytitle: Efficacy of Vitamin C treatment for children with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease type 1A
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Efficacy of ascorbic acid supplementation in children with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease type 1A to improve muscle strength and peripheral nerve function

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Other human genetics and inherited disorders

interventions.interventions: Experimental group: Daily oral ascorbic acid supplementation for 12 months as per the established age-specific tolerable upper intake levels of ascorbic acid (US Food and Nutrition Board Institute of Medicine, 2000).
interventions.comparator: Control group: Daily oral placebo for 12 months.

primaryOutcome.outcome: a) Isometric muscle strength of the foot and ankle
b) Disease progression via nerve conduction studies of the median nerve

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Neurophysiological studies of the median nerve, isometric hand strength, functional ability, health-related quality of life
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured at baseline and at 12-months follow-up

eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Pregnancy; glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency; hereditary hemochromatosis; thalassemia; polycythemia; leukaemia or sideroblastic anaemia; sickle cell anaemia; acute foot injuries and recent foot surgery; inflammatory arthritis; diabetes.

trial_design.sequence: Permuted block randomisation stratified for centre and age

ethicsAndSummary.summary:
The purpose of this trial is to determine the effect of high-dose vitamin C on muscle strength, nerve function, gross motor coordination and health-related quality of life in children with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease type 1A.
We hypothesise that muscle strength, nerve function, gross motor coordination and health-related quality of life will be greater in children with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease type 1A who receive dietary vitamin C supplementation compared to children receiving the placebo.
ethicsAndSummary.publication: Burns J. Ouvrier RA. Yiu EM. Joseph PD. Kornberg AJ. Fahey MC. Ryan MM. Ascorbic acid for CharcotMarieTooth disease type 1A in children: a randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, safety and efficacy trial. Lancet Neurology. 8 (6) 537-544, 2009.
